body.p:
An Interview with Humboldt―His Letter to
Mr. Heine.
Mr. Heine, a talented German artist, who has
been for some time residing in this city, is about
to accompany Mr. E. G. Squier on his scientific
exploration of the antiquities of Central Ameri-
ca. In order that he might overlook no advantage
to be derived from such a journey, he recently
wrote to his father, in Berlin, enclosing a letterletter to
Humboldt, in which he asked of that philosopher
to somesome information in regard to the subjects
most worthy of notice, to be met with in his pro-
jected tour. Mr. Heine has kindly furnished us
with an extract from his father’s letter, describing
his interview with Humboldt, together with a
copy of Humboldt’s letter to himself. We trans-
late from the former the following passages,
which contain an interesting description of the
Nestor of scientific men.

“I found this great philosopher the most amia-
ble old man whom I have ever met―in one word,
the friend of Man, as of Nature. The mild, clear
eye, the friendly features surrounded with a halo
of silver hair, made a powerful impression on me,
and I cannot now decide whether reverence or an
instant affection for him, was the prevailing feel-
ing in my mind. He speaks very fast, yet dis-
tinctly; his voice is soft and winning, and his
slightly bent stature scarcely betrays the veteran
of 81 years. He invited me to sit with your
mother on the sofa, and drew a cane chair famil-
iarly toward me. In answer to a movement of
mine he said he “never sat on sofas.” I will en-
deavor to recall his own words, as near as possi-
ble:

“‘Pray do not interrupt me, for my time is
very limited; only answer me. Your son has
written me a charming letter, which has given
me great pleasure and fully informs me about his
plans. I know Mr. Squier and am already ac-
quainted with his undertaking. I have also
spoken to the King about it, and he is pleased
that a young German artist will be Mr. Squier’s
companion. The King has much respect for Mr.
Squier; but was at first a little astounded con-
cerning his reports of the monstrous dimensions
of the ancient American monuments. It is
therefore agreeable to His Majesty to find those
reports so thoroughly confirmed, and he takes no
less interest in the undertaking, than myself.
You cannot think how keenly everything inter-
ests me, which is going on in the great distance,
to discover for us new truths and beauties,’―and
here Humboldt’s clear eyes said plainly that he
would willingly be young again, to do as he has
done, as if he did not already wear enough of
well earned hours. I wish I could better des-
cribe his dignified and yet unpretending expres-
sion, which impressed me strongly with the pre-
sence of a great man. ‘The highest degree of
perfection which Man can reach,’ said he, ‘is
the knowledge of what still remains for him
to achieve. I have arranged for your son,’ he
continued, ‘what I wish him to do for me. But
wait a moment, I must write something more.’
With that he went into an adjoining room, and
soon returned with two volumes, smiling as he
said: ‘If I want to write well, I must write very
slowly―yes yes, these 81 years!’

“I asked whether he desired I should give him
further details, when I should again hear from
you. ‘It will give me pleasure,’ he answered,
‘to hear them from your own lips, but don’t
write, for then I should very likely hear nothing.
I receive 5,000 letters a year; how should I read
them all? Many must necessarily lie unread,
though this troubles me. You cannot think how
many claims are made upon me, all of which I
am expected to answer. See, here are notes
which I got up at 5 o’clock this morning to write.
This very day I was obliged to pay a large amount
of postage, and for what? A piece of embroidery,
which I was expected to set up as a lottery for a
charitable purpose. Now the design of this is
praiseworthy, and therefore one most do the fa-
vor―But I shall keep my promise and send to-
morrow a friendly letter to your son. I most
heartily wish him a fortunate result in whatever
he undertakes.’ I reminded him of your promise
concerning the palm-blossoms, ‘Ah,’ said he,
‘how can I describe them more minutely? If I
could go myself, I would be better able to do it,’
and again the longing for new activity and new
discovery shone in his eyes. I then left him; but
the half hour I spent in his company will always
remain one of the most delightful reminiscences
of my life.”

We also translate the following letter from
Humboldt to Mr. Heine:

“ At a season when I am unusually active and
preoccupied, my dear Herr Heine, I can only
thank you in a few words for your very friendly
letter. I consider you fortunate that your talents
have met with a favorable opportunity to repre-
sent the grand scenes of the tropic world and the
venerable remains of ancient culture. I recom-
mend to you the correct illustration of the vol-
canic peaks as much more important than that of
the physiognomy of the vegetable world, which
has already been enriched by the extensive and
faithful sketches of Rugendas, Edward, Hilde-
brandt and Bellermann. Still, those great lakes,
filled with islands, must present many new fea-
tures of landscape painting. As regards the mon-
uments, (in Yucatan, Guatemala and Nicaragua,)
there is a great lack of illustrations which pre-
serve the correct proportions. Your architectural
knowledge will enable you to supply this defi-
ciency.

“The eighth edition of my folio work in three
parts, Vue des Cordillères, will, I think, be of
most service to you. You will find in it a multi-
tude of views which may throw some light upon
what discoveries you make in the department of
ornamental sculpture, with which all the ancient
edifices of the Aztecs the inhabitants of Yucatan
and the southern region adjoining the Isthmus,
are richly covered. In Yucatan there is a species
of pointed arch to be found, constructed, however,
from a series of overlapping stones, as in the old
Egyptian monuments. You may there be able to
find sculptures of the Aztec calendar, traditions
of the four ages of the world, or the name Wotun,
which seems to have some connection with that
of Odin, and stands as authority for our division
of the year.

“I rejoice at your connection with Mr. Squier,
whom I beg you to assure of my particular re-
gard, since I have to thank him for his admirable
researches among the enigmatical monuments of
the United States. May you find that enjoyment
which must certainly crown your laudable spirit
of enterprise! Humboldt.”
